Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Isis Nike. Isis is shown with wings, wearing a stephane (diadem) and holding a pomegranate. Mould-made and hollow. Traces of white (gypsum?) coating. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably locally produced at the Naukratis Terracottas workshop that operated during the 3rd to the 2nd century BC. Isis-Nike in a Greek style, with wings, rather than the Egyptian version of Isis-Nike, wingless, usually on horseback, carrying a palm frond (Bailey 2008, no. 3009, 3010, 3011 from Naukratis). Like the Egyptian versions, this Nike is also carrying a small spherical pot.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.155) (Phase 1)
